Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Correlating Geospatial Data Lineage and Positional Accuracy for Excavation Damage Prevention

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to explore methods that model and quantify the uncertainty associated with recorded underground utility location data. Locational uncertainty is the error associated with the methods of mapping underground utilities, and will be modeled as three-dimensional geometric shapes that correspond to the probability that these shapes contain the utilities. Locational uncertainty is dependent on locational accuracy, which will be estimated from data lineage - the format and process used to collect data. The premise associated with this research is that locational uncertainty results from inaccurate locational information that, in turn, is a function of data lineage. The utility data and its quantified uncertainty will be integrated with excavation operations, and communicated to operators by blending the geometry and attribute information with operators' views of the work environment using video-see-through augmented reality. Field experiments will be conducted with industry partners to validate the proposed geospatial uncertainty model and evaluate its benefits of improving excavation safety.

If successful, the research results will lead to improvements in construction operations such as, excavation in the presence of buried utilities, drilling in the presence of hidden obstructions, and robotic construction in the absence of exact prior knowledge of the environment. The project will impact education by promoting subsurface utility engineering as an area of specialization. A diverse group of under-represented students will participate in the project through active collaboration with the Women in Science and Engineering, and the Minority Engineering Program offices at Purdue and the University of Michigan. In summary, the societal benefits of the project are expected to be the improved safety of excavation and other construction operations, and the multi-disciplinary education and training of current and future engineers in an emerging engineering specialty.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Of all the 5,618 significant pipeline incidents that occurred in the United States from 1994 to 2013, 21.8% were caused by excavation damage, resulting in 142 fatalities, 491 injuries, and over five billions of property damages. The recurrent pipeline incidents are attributed to: (1) the lack of complete and reliable data regarding utility location and dimension, (2) the drawback of communicating utility location and associated positional uncertainty to end-users, and (3) the absence of an automatic mechanism for utility compliance checking during constructions. This project addressed the above problems by developing prototype for utility data collection, creating novel algorithms to estimate utility depths and dimensions, deriving mathematical models to account for and visualize positional uncertainties inherent in utility location data, and designing computational methods to automate spatial reasoning to check utility compliance. These unique capabilities can enable engineers to access accurate utility information, visually perceive the positional uncertainties associated with a utility line, and proactively identify noncompliance to avoid disastrous utility strikes. Hence, the paradigm created in this project offers significant potential to reduce the utility incidents and improve the safety and productivity of the utility and construction industry.

The main research outcomes are reported in three phases. First, this research created a novel algorithm to detect, locate, and characterize underground utilities using a hybrid system of ground penetrating radar (GPR) and global positioning system (GPS) under generic scenarios. This algorithmic technique relaxed the conventional constraints of requiring GPR to perpendicularly scan a buried utility line and addressed the computational limitation of requiring prior information on the velocity of GPR electromagnetic (EM) wave or utility dimensions. Second, this research assessed the locating accuracy of the hybrid GPR/GPS system and mathematically modeled the positional uncertainty as a 3D probabilistic error band. The 3D probabilistic error band facilitates the visualization of utility lines and inherent uncertainty in a geographical information system (GIS) and augmented reality (AR) environment. Third, this research integrated natural language processing (NLP) and spatial reasoning/proximity analysis to automate utility compliance checking based on the premise that utility locations are acquired and excavator movements are monitored. Field experiments validated the above research outcomes and demonstrated their efficacies.
